deliberation: Checked the prophetic formula for figurative language. The key phrase is "the word of YHWH came to me," which treats the divine word as an active agent that comes. This is a conventional prophetic metaphor/personification for divine communication; no other figures (simile, hyperbole, irony, etc.) appear.

vehicle: a "word" that travels and arrives like a person or object
ground: initiative and directedness of the message from sender to recipient
transfer and arrival of communication
communication dynamics
posture: presents the message as authoritative and originating outside the prophet
instances.explanation: The divine "word" is depicted as if it were an entity that can come to the prophet, personifying and metaphorically describing the experience of revelation.

deliberation: Considered "son of man" as a title (largely conventional, not used figuratively in context) and "set your face toward the mountains of Israel" as a likely idiom. The phrase about the face being set toward the mountains uses body-part language for directed opposition/attention, functioning as an idiomatic metaphor/metonymy. Addressing the mountains will be personified more explicitly in v.3.

instances.english_text: turn/set your face toward the mountains of Israel

vehicle: the physical face turned and fixed toward an object
ground: orientation, focus, and resolve directed at a target
connection between bodily direction and inner intention
embodied cognition
posture: depicts Ezekiel’s role as determined opponent and herald of judgment
instances.explanation: The prophet is told to "set his face" toward the mountains; the literal face stands metonymically for attitude and resolve, forming an idiomatic metaphor for taking a firm, oppositional prophetic stance.

deliberation: This verse has layered figurative language. (1) The mountains are addressed and told to "hear," a clear personification. (2) The list of "mountains, hills, ravines, valleys" functions metonymically for the whole idolatrous cultic landscape of Israel. (3) "I will bring a sword against you" uses "sword" as metonymy for invading warfare and judgment. I treat these as three distinct but related expressions.

instances.english_text: O mountains of Israel, hear the word of the Sovereign GOD
target: the land and cultic centers of Israel, especially the people who worship there
vehicle: animate audience with ears and understanding
ground: the mountains represent the enduring setting of Israel’s sin and thus are treated as if morally accountable hearers
association between place and its inhabitants’ deeds
moral geography
posture: heightens the seriousness of the oracle by staging creation itself as listening to God’s decree
instances.explanation: The inanimate mountains are commanded to "hear" God’s word, personifying the landscape as listening recipients of the oracle.

instances.hebrew_text: כֹּה־אָמַ֣ר אֲדֹנָ֣י יֱהֹוִ֠ה לֶהָרִ֨ים וְלַגְּבָע֜וֹת לָאֲפִיקִ֣ים וְלַגֵּיאָי֗וֹת

target: all the idolatrous worship sites and those who use them throughout the land
cultic high places and their worshipers

ground: these topographical features are the characteristic settings of the high places; mentioning them stands for the entire system of idolatrous worship in the land
place representing its practices and people
metonymic association

instances.explanation: The varied landforms function metonymically (and in a list similar to a merism) for all the cultic sites and worship practices spread across Israel.

means–effect association

instances.explanation: "Sword" functions metonymically and metaphorically for the warfare and invading army God will send as judgment.

deliberation: The verse describes altars being ruined, incense stands smashed, and slain cast in front of idols. These are gruesome, but the language itself is direct and concrete, not figurative: no metaphors, similes, or personifications beyond literal cultic and military imagery.

Again the description of corpses and bones scattered around altars is graphic but straightforward. The actions (casting corpses, scattering bones) are literal judgments in prophetic imagery rather than figurative turns of phrase. I do not detect metaphor, simile, personification, or other figures in the wording itself.

Most of the verse is literal description of cities devastated and cultic objects destroyed. One phrase stands out: the altars are said to become "desolate and guilty"/"bear punishment"—a verb of guilt/punishment that is normally predicated of persons is applied to inanimate altars, which personifies them as liable for guilt.

instances.english_text: Thus your altars shall be laid waste and bear their punishment / become guilty
target: the status of the idolatrous altars in God’s judgment
vehicle: a person who becomes guilty and bears punishment
ground: altars, as centers of illegitimate worship, are treated like moral agents that incur guilt and punishment
transfer of personal moral categories to objects
moral personification
posture: intensifies the condemnation of the cult by treating even the structures as culpable
instances.explanation: By saying the altars "become guilty" or "bear punishment," the text personifies them as if they were moral agents who can incur guilt.

deliberation: The verse states that the slain will fall in the midst of the people and that they will know YHWH. These are standard prophetic statements of concrete death and cognitive/moral recognition. No non-literal imagery, simile, or special idiom is used beyond ordinary covenantal language.

This verse promises a remnant who escape the sword and are scattered among the nations. Though "remnant" is a theological motif, here it functions as an ordinary term for survivors, and "sword" and "scattering" are used in their normal prophetic sense of literal warfare and exile (already picked up figuratively in v.3). No additional figurative expression specific to this wording is evident.

This verse is rich in figurative language. The heart is called "whoring"—a metaphor for covenant infidelity—and the eyes are likewise said to "play the harlot" after idols. These expressions combine metaphor (unfaithful sexuality) with metonymy (heart/eyes for the whole inner person). I treat the whoring heart and the whoring eyes as two distinct figurative instances.

instances.hebrew_text: אֲשֶׁ֣ר נִשְׁבַּרְתִּי אֶת־לִבָּ֣ם הַזּוֹנֶ֗ה אֲשֶׁר־סָר֙ מֵֽעָלַ֔י
instances.english_text: how I was brokenhearted through their faithless hearts that turned away from Me (lit. "when I broke their whoring heart which turned away from Me")

vehicle: a heart that is a prostitute/faithless sexual partner
ground: both prostitution and idolatry involve betrayal of an exclusive relationship and seeking other partners/loves
shared notions of unfaithfulness and illicit desire
covenantal-relationship analogy
posture: frames Israel’s idolatry as deeply personal betrayal wounding God, not mere ritual error
instances.explanation: Israel’s heart is metaphorically described as a "whoring" heart, personifying their inner disposition as an unfaithful sexual partner to depict covenant-breaking idolatry.

instances.english_text: and their eyes that lusted/played the harlot after their fetishes

vehicle: eyes that act as prostitutes pursuing clients
ground: wandering, desirous eyes and a prostitute both actively seek out forbidden partners
connection between looking with desire and unfaithful pursuit
desire/infidelity analogue
posture: portrays their gaze as actively complicit in betrayal, not passive
instances.explanation: Their "eyes" are personified and metaphorically called "whoring" as they follow idols, using body-part metonymy (eyes for desire) and the sexual infidelity metaphor to depict their idolatrous longing.

deliberation: The verse states that they will know YHWH and recognize that He did not speak "for nothing" in bringing this evil. While "evil" here means calamity, that is standard prophetic usage, and "not without cause" is a literal legal-moral assertion. No clear metaphor, simile, or other figure stands out beyond normal theological language.

The commands to clap hands, stamp feet, and say "Aha!" are symbolic prophetic gestures, but in the text they are literal instructions for embodied sign-acts, not figurative phrases. "Fall by the sword, famine, and pestilence" continues the literal triad of judgments. I do not isolate a distinct figurative linguistic expression here.

The distributions of death by pestilence, sword, and famine are literal judgments. The key figurative phrase is "Thus I will spend my fury upon them" (וְכִלֵּיתִ֥י חֲמָתִ֖י בָּֽם), where wrath is conceptualized as something that can be used up or exhausted, a common metaphor/idiom for divine anger.

instances.english_text: Thus I will spend My fury upon them
target: the completion of God’s judgmental anger against Israel
vehicle: using up or exhausting a finite resource
consumption of a stored substance (e.g., provisions, energy)
ground: both exhausting a supply and fully executing wrath involve finishing what is held or intended so that nothing remains
idea of completion and depletion
process/completion analogy
posture: underscores that judgment will be total and not partial or tentative
instances.explanation: God’s "fury" is portrayed as a quantity that can be spent or used up, an idiomatic metaphor for completely carrying out His wrath.

deliberation: The verse revisits slain among idols and a catalogue of locations: every high hill, all mountaintops, under every green tree, every leafy oak. This formula in the prophets is a stock way to denote all idolatrous high-place worship, using specific locations as metonymy and functioning similarly to a merism. I treat this as one composite metonymic expression.

vehicle: specific topographical and arboreal locations (high hills, mountaintops, green trees, oaks)
ground: these specific places were characteristic sites of pagan worship; citing them stands for all such idolatrous practice throughout the land, in a list functioning like a merism
place representing practice and its extent
metonymic/meristic association
posture: emphasizes how pervasive and entrenched the idolatry is across Israel’s landscape
instances.explanation: The repeated formula "every high hill ... under every green tree" uses characteristic locations as metonymy (in a near-meristic way) for the whole spread of idolatrous high-place worship.

deliberation: Most of the verse’s devastation language is literal prophetic description of desolation. The phrase "I will stretch out My hand against them" is a standard metaphor/anthropomorphism: God’s "hand" stands for His active power in judgment, and stretching it out portrays decisive action.

instances.english_text: I will stretch out My hand against them

vehicle: a human hand stretched out to strike or act against someone
instrument of physical action and attack
ground: both a stretched-out hand and God’s act of judgment involve directed, intentional exertion of power against an object
hand as metonymy for effective power
agency/power association
posture: presents divine judgment in vivid, personal terms as if God were a warrior or judge taking action
instances.explanation: God is portrayed anthropomorphically as stretching out His "hand"—a metonymy and metaphor for His active, forceful intervention in judgment.
